717526f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street
717526f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, south from, but not including, 47th Street.
In the centre background is the New York Theatre, which will stand
until 1935. Below it is the Hotel Cadillac. In the right back-
ground is the Hotel Astor, and below it, a part of the New York
Times Building.
May, 1909.
Brown Brothers.

713300f-a.title: Manhattan: 47th Street (East) - Broadway
713300f-a.text:
47th Street, south side, west froa 228 West 47th Street, west of
Broadway.
January 27, 1928.
P.L. Sperr.

713297f-a.title: Manhattan: 47th Street (East) - Broadway
713297f-a.text:
228-248 West 47th Street, south side, between Broadway and
Eighth Avenue. This is the Hotel Edison, a striking example of
modernistio architecture. Herbert J. Krapp is the architect.
About 1930.
4A9StRothachiT6.

717532f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street (West)
717532f-a.text:
1570-1564 Broadway, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of West 47th Street.
The 2-story building comprises a double lot, Nos. 1570-1568, with the 11-story
office building, No. 1564 adjoining. The Palace Theatre, a former vaude-
ville house now (1937), shows only motion pictures. Considering all the
former aspirations of variety players to perform at this house, motion pict-
uures are a tragedy. The theatre actually is in the 5-story building at the
rear of both of these lots; with an entmance and lobby through the office
building. These buildings, aeographically on Seventh Ave., form a part of
Times Square and bear Broadway numbers.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

713298f-c.title: Manhattan: 47th Street (East) - Broadway
713298f-c.text:
West 47th Street, west from a point midway between Broadway and Eighth
Ave., ahnd across the latter, showing two theatres in the northern end
of the block and facing each other. The Mansfield, and Biltmore Theatres
bear Hos. 256 and 261 respectively. The building partially slown on the
extreme left of No. 1 is the new Edison Hotel. The two tenement houses
north of same bear Nos. 250 and 252. This set consists of two negative
and two positiveiviews.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.

723553f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street
723553f-b.text:
(1 & 2)
Broadway, east side, south from West 47th Street, and showing the
easterly portion of an area known as Times Square; a name received from
the proximity of the Times Building, which appears in the center of this
view. On the left is the Palace Theatre entrance, at No. 1564. This set
consists of a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Ng 7i
(3 & 4)
A detail of same in the opposite direction and showing the entrance
to Loew's State Theatre at No. 1538 Broadway. This set also consists of
a negative and a positive.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
No4S Neg 042

723539f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street
723539f-a.text:
Duffy Square: The recently erected Father Duffy monument.
Thnis individual was cnaplain of the "fignting 69th Regiment, New
York Natuonal Guards" of World War Pame. In the background is
Broadway north of W. 47tn Street.
September 22, 1939
George D. Chinn

717525f-c.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street (West)
717525f-c.text:
BroadWAy. east side, at West 47th Street, showing the Palace Theatre
(No. 1564 Broadway) and Loews Mayfair Theatre. The latter is technically
on Seventh Ave., which at this point regains its identity after traveraing
Times Square. This is a set of two views, consisting of a negative and
a positive.
September 1935.
W.P.A. Photo.
The same and showing a more extensive view northward on Seventh
Ave. (left).
September 14, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

717529f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street (West)
717529f.text:
Broadway (Times Square), east side, south across W. 47th Street.
The Palace Theatre is on the left and the B. M. T. subway entrance
on the right.
1938-9
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume
"Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

717530f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street (West)
717530f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from West 47th, to and including 48th
Streets. Also shown is West 47th Street, at and adjoining the N.E.
corner of Broadway.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

717535f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 47th Street
717535f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from 47th to 48th Streets. In the centre
is the Strand Theatre.
February 22, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
